summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami office to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez was Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager who attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers of what are believed to be additional underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the individual to whom Alfredo Rodriguez was employed. The address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain contact information for his additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records
events.description: Telephone records were generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 2010) for the investigation.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (DocLab - Telephone Application Audit Processing Team, 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.
The FBI was processing telephone records from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for the period from September 2001 onward.
The document is a formal request for the FBI's Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate these records for incorporation into the Bureau's Telephone Application (TA) investigative tool.
The address book was obtained by Rodriguez during his employment with Epstein, and he attempted to sell it to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of turning it over in response to federal subpoenas.
